pros:
Let me be clear. I don't hate this company. This is one of the best companies to work for. I just hate the job I landed in and my cowardice of not leaving as soon as possible

Sun Based model is implemented which means after 9 hrs of work your manager can't ask you to stay back and work more. After that you are free to do whatever you wanted to.

There are several events conducted here which makes for a good inclusive work atmosphere.

Benefits are not as good as some other companies but min hike is 20 percent per year.
cons:
This job in particular is hell on earth. No words otherwise. 

You'll be given a set of utterances and have to hear it and transcribe it. You have to wear extremely heavy headphones to listen and transcribe the utterances.

You are not allowed to leave your desk even for bathroom break unless you want to get a call out from managers. You'll have 1hr break in between total of nine hours and you have to use it for both bathroom breaks and for breakfast/lunch/dinner.

If you think this is the worst part... hell no. The worst part is when they measure the quality. Quality used to be measured by seeing the number of mistakes we made in our transcription. They used to put the quality percentage at 95%. Difficult but achievable. But now they introduced a new way of measuring quality. It's called BPS.

Let me give you a scenario. You have1-2 yrs experience in a job and you are told to do a better job than a person with more than 4 yrs of experience. Is it possible to do so? In this job it's impossible. BPS means you have to do a better job than people who have more than 1-2 yrs exp on you. I never went under 95% quality before. Now even when I got 100% qual I was fired because I did not perform 3% better then employees more tenured than me.
I mean how can I calculate that. We will be saved if the tenured guys make mistakes. That's not quality that's dumb luck.

When I said this to my manager before getting fired they say your fellow employees are doing so. Trust me this is not quality that is luck because their quality is 67 in old scenario.

Wonder when did Amazon's principles turn from "Hire and develop the best" to "Hire and develop the luckiest"

pros:
Flexible shift available
Isolated (for introverts)
Benefits
Decent facility

LONGER REVIEW:
This is for people who are thinking about working at this facility. It is not a traditional fulfillment center. We did not pack customer orders. This is just a center that distributes orders to other fulfillment centers. There are two main roles if you are new , stower and picker (they have more, but 9 times of ten you will be placed there of new). When you are trained, you will get put in one of the two areas, you can't do both. I was a picker (outbound) so I can really only talk about that. All I can say about stowers (inbound) is that they get orders from vendors and put them on the shelves. I don't really know anything else. Both roles are PIT (Google "Amazon PIT" so you can see what I mean) based. AT our facility PIT machine goes up 40 feet in the air. Yes, you will go up in the air with it and a cage. You have on a harness and during training they try to help you get over that fear. I have a bad fear of heights but for the most part was able to get over it because of the exposure and the aisles being so narrow, it feels a little less risky.  Pickers go into aisles and find boxes based on the handledheld instructions. So it will tell you what aisle, row, height and bin(which holds a bunch of boxes).  When you get to the bin you scan it and then look for a particular box. Once you find the box, you scan it, put it in the cage attached to your PIT and do it again until your cage is full or the handheld tells you to drop off your cage. You take it to the loading dock (you don't have to empty it... someone else does that... thankfully) and get a empty cage and do it all again. 70% of the time If it tells you your first item is on aisle 170, you will pretty much stay on that aisle and for a bunch of boxes (maybe 30+) so you don't have to spend time trying to get to the next aisle. When you do exit the aisle, a lot of times, the next stop is the aisle that right next to it or close to each other. If you look and see it telling you to drive across the building without a notice saying you are changing zones, you are probably read it wrong. Look again ..To me, finding the aisle was a little tricky sometimes because I didn't go consistently and never remembered where aisles were. The hardest part though is finding a small package in a bin that has a bunch of items in it. You sometimes have to take other heavier boxes out to get to your one box. It's annoying. And sometimes the stowers don't stow right (or pickers don't put the boxes back right) and so the labels aren't easily visible and you have to lift a box just to see a label. I hated that. I was always praying for my box to be at the front. This is especially true for deep aisles. I HATED THOSE. MY opinion is that deep aisles should be reserved for big boxes only. No small boxes. It's too hard to go through 30 - 50 boxes with a reach tool. You wanna climb in just to get to it quicker but that's dangerous (don't do it). You do have to lift some heavy boxes....not anything that requires two people but heavy enough where you will say it's heavy in your head. I felt a little weak for the job sometimes. This isn't a job for people who get hurt easily or tire easily or who have physical health issues, like back problems....The aisles I loved were the pallet/rainbow aisles. On those, you don't have to look for a specific package 98% of the time...the whole bin is all the same product with no sticker, so you just grab one, put the sticker on and scan it. That's it. With all that said, I didn't hate picking but I didn't love it either. It's one of those jobs where if you like a challenge of finding stuff fast (like on those hidden picture games) you may like this position. It's very isolated work (which I personally loved) but that's not for everybody. You cannot wear headphones (which sucked) because it's quiet otherwise. The 3day (10 hr each day) training consisted of a lot of sitting and waiting...when we weren't doing anything, we watched videos ...a big waste of time learning stuff that barely affected me. On the 2nd day I started to learn how to drive the PIT and practice. You practice on wire guided aisles and non wire areas. That was fun to finally get hands on after hours of sitting The previous day and half of day 2. The lesson on how to actually find boxes lasted only 10 minutes at the most which makes no sense to me as that was the thing I did the most. They should give you tips and tricks on how to do it quickly. They don't. The people are okay. No one is mean or nasty... Just felt like no one was necessarily happy to be there. Understandable. The people in HR are super nice. Great attitudes.  I ended up leaving for another facility because I needed a better schedule (I was reduced time flex but had to do 30 hours a week and could never get in that frequently) . If it had been closer to my house and only 15 hours a week, I may have stayed a little while longer. Maybe.

pros:
-If you are a competitive, go-getter, who does not mind working long hours, this is the company for you. 
-Decent sign on bonus.

-Processes and products change weekly if not daily. Never 100% sure on what pertains to your role. 
-Yearly raises are less than inflation, even if you are in the "Good" employee bucket. A 1% yearly raise is insulting. Especially as the company experiences significant growth. No bonus opportunity unless you are in Sales. 
-Expected to take on multiple projects outside job description in order to receive a promotion. Even then, if you have a bad quarter that can impact your ability to receive a promotion in the next year.
-Lots of overtime if you are in the US and no compensation for it to be seen as a "good" employee. 
-Decent PTO, but not enough coverage so you feel like you can never take it. 
-Lots of talk about mental health, but no action or support from higher ups. 
-Expected to perform 110%+ at all times, even through a global pandemic. 
-Managers are often focused on their own career growth, and not of their teams which makes it hard to get support you need to grow your career. One bad manager can ruin your chance at promotion. 
-Promotion requirements are constantly changing. 
-No flexibility on working remote if you are single (but if you are married and have kids, you will likely be granted the exception).
-Turnover rate is high but management does nothing to change this.
-Increased focus on diversity, but so far this has felt like lip service.
